title: mas kindness
intro: For many children, Christmas is the most exciting time of the year when they look forward to all the presents Santa Claus will bring. But for families who struggle to buy food they can’t afford presents for Christmas day. Neil and Alice discuss how some charities are helping these families in need.
this_week_question: In the famous classic story A Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens, what does Ebenezer Scrooge buy the Cratchit family for Christmas dinner? Is it…
You can hear the right answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: somebody who loves money but hates spending it
the day before something e.g. Christmas Eve
an imaginary old man with a white beard and red clothes who brings children presents at Christmas time
a place where toys are given away free to people in need
someone who has the same opinion as you
giving free help to people who need it
being part of a group who are united in support for an idea
statistical information about a population and the groups of people in it
unusual because it comes from another country

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm Neil… Did you get all your Christmas shopping done, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: I did, Neil. And I spent a small fortune – and that means a lot of money!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I hate buying all those presents that people just don't really want.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Oh, Neil, you grumpy old Scrooge! And I hope you realise that the subject of today's show is Christmas kindness!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh dear. I might be grumpy – and that means bad-tempered – but I'm not a scrooge! I don't mind spending money – I just don't know what to buy people. Ebenezer Scrooge is the main character in Charles Dickens' novel A Christmas Carol . He's a miser – and that means someone who loves money but hates spending it.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Indeed. Well, on the subject of A Christmas Carol , Neil, at the end of the story, what does Scrooge buy the Cratchit family for Christmas dinner? Is it… a) a goose? b) a turkey? Or c) a chicken?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hmm. Well, I haven't read the book so I'm going to guess a) a goose.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out later if you chose the right answer. Now, Neil, I agree that Christmas shopping can sometimes feel pointless – but we mustn't forget what a magical time Christmas is for young children.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's true. I remember how hard it was to get to sleep on Christmas Eve – worrying that Santa Claus would get stuck in our chimney.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, well, eve means the day before something – in this case, Christmas Day. Parents tell their children that Santa Claus – an imaginary old man with a white beard and red clothes – will bring them presents at Christmas time. In the UK children believe that Santa comes down the chimney to get into the house.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But it's not all fun. Increasing numbers of people these days are struggling for money at this time of year. Having enough food to feed their family is what matters most and buying presents comes further down the list. So let's listen now to a BBC Scotland report by Laura Maxwell. She's talking about a special event with lots of presents.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Laura Maxwell, BBC Scotland, and Beatrice Caddell LM: Beatrice Cadell has just celebrated her 80 th birthday. And instead of presents for her, she asked her friends to buy toys. BC: Everyone that turned up to that birthday do was absolutely brilliant. Absolutely brilliant. And it's good for something like this. It's even better. It's even better – you know – somebody else can benefit. We don't need it. We're old.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: So Beatrice is celebrating her birthday and she told friends and family to buy toys instead of presents for her.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Right. She had the generous idea of donating – or giving – the toys to a toy bank – a place where toys are given away free to people in need. The toy bank then distributed Beatrice's toys to parents who couldn't afford to buy presents for their children at Christmas.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. So Beatrice is happy that children can benefit – or be helped by her. She says she doesn't need presents. A woman after your own heart , Neil!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Indeed! And that means Beatrice has the same opinion as me! Well, that's a great example of Christmas charity – and charity means giving free help to people who need it.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. And here's another example, Neil. Last year in London, twenty tons of presents were donated, wrapped, and delivered to a local hospital to cheer up sick children who couldn't go home for Christmas.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Were they delivered in Santa's sleigh?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: No Neil, they were delivered in a big double-decker bus! Let's hear about the volunteers who made this happen.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Volunteer Lots of different groups of people come together under the banner of kindness – so religious people come together, corporate people come together, young people, old people – it seems to be something that stretches across many many many different demographics.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Under the banner of kindness – what does that mean, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, being under the banner of something means being part of a group who are united in support for an idea. And in this case, different people came together to do something kind for sick children.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And demographics? What's that?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Demographics means statistical information about a population and the groups of people in it. People from different groups in society are working together – the old and the young, religious people, corporate – or business – people.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And this talk of kindness is making me feel more in the mood for Christmas!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: I can see that, Ebenezer. You've got a smile on your face! Now, earlier in the show, I asked: At the end of the story, what does Scrooge buy the Cratchit family for Christmas dinner? Is it… a) a goose? b) a turkey? Or c) a chicken?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said a) a goose.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. And you were wrong, Neil! The answer is b) a turkey.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That makes me a goose.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: It certainly does. Scrooge buys the Cratchit family the prize turkey hanging. Delicious! A Christmas Carol is a lovely story. Everybody should read it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And did you know that although turkeys are traditional Christmas food now, they weren't in Dickens's time.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: I see...

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: They were exotic back then – and that means unusual because it comes from another country. The story was written in 1843. Now how about hearing the words we learned today, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: They are: a small fortune grumpy miser eve Santa Claus donating toy bank benefit after your own heart charity under the banner of something demographics exotic

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Merry Christmas, everybody!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Merry Christmas!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Please join us again soon!

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
